arts.ttl: Blackpool end Reading unbeaten run with quickfire second-half goals
arts.sum: Blackpool ended Reading's 11-match unbeaten run after two quickfire second half goals at Bloomfield Road, winning 2-0. Reading had not lost since January 28 and looked to cement their place in the play-offs but knew it was a tall order against the Tangerines, who had only lost two of their last 14 and are traditionally a bogey team for the Royals. Sonny Carey and Olly Casey scored within 10 minutes of the second half to put the match beyond the Royals, who saw lots of the ball but lacked cutting edge throughout. Noel Hunt made just one change from Saturday's 3-1 win over Peterborough United, Jayden Wareham coming in from the start in place of Mamadi Camara, with Kelvin Ehibhatiomhan moving out wide.

arts.ttl: Reading boss on Blackpool defeat and end of unbeaten run after 'minutes of madness'
arts.sum: Reading boss Noel Hunt spoke of 'three minutes of madness' as his side's unbeaten run came to an end at 11 matches with Blackpool easing to a 3-0 victory. Reading impressed in a close first half, but two goals in the first 10 minutes of the second period but the tie beyond the Royals, a stoppage time third rounding off a disappointing evening at Bloomfield Road. "Three minutes of madness and a couple of mistakes, at this level if you dwell on the ball for a second you get punished. After that, we lost a bit of structure for a minute or two, they take a quick free kick and you’re chasing the game. For the first half I thought we controlled the majority of it but to concede two goals as we did, you’re always chasing, and we leave ourselves a little bit open for the sucker punch at the end." Blackpool are now just four points outside the play-offs, three behind Reading, and showed their experience throughout, Hunt pointing out that some of their side were multiple league title winners.

arts.ttl: Sonny Carey scores twice as Blackpool end Reading’s unbeaten run
arts.sum: The Tangerines improved their play-off prospects with victory on Tuesday night.

arts.ttl: Live updates: Reading look to keep up form in with seaside trip to Blackpool
arts.sum: Reading are looking to pick up a 12th unbeaten match as they travel to Blackpool. The Royals last won a league match at Bloomfield Road over 20 years ago and Steve Bruce's side sit just five points behind Noel Hunt's Royals.

arts.ttl: Blackpool chief congratulates Reading for 'fantastic' form ahead of meeting
arts.sum: Blackpool boss Steve Bruce has congratulated Reading for their 'fantastic' form ahead of tonight's meeting. Bruce, a legendary player and manager with over 1,000 games, was a hero of Noel Hunt's growing up and was the opponent for his first home match in charge, beating Reading 3-0 in December. However, since then the Royals have embarked on an 11-game unbeaten run and now head to Bloomfield Road occupying a play-off space with eight matches to go. The Tangerines are not in bad form themselves, losing just two in their last 14, although 15 draws from their 39 fixtures have them sat 10th and five points behind Reading.

arts.ttl: Reading boss on availability of central defenders ahead of Blackpool trip
arts.sum: Reading defender Harlee Dean is set to miss 'a few weeks' with a hip injury. The 33-year-old has been a bit-part player for most of his near-two-year stay in Berkshire but was in fine form during a spell at the turn of the year as Amadou Mbengue missed out with a knee injury. Featuring earlier in the month against Wrexham, the experienced campaigner hobbled off and has seen a specialist to get to the root of the problem. Missing from the squad for Saturday's 3-1 win over Peterborough United, Noel Hunt confirmed he will not be seen for at least a few weeks. "Harlee went and saw a specialist yesterday [Friday]; he has a consultation on Monday. We will see how he goes. Hopefully it’s not too bad but I can’t see Harlee being back for a few weeks."

arts.ttl: Reading boss looks ahead to tricky tie at 'dogged and physically strong' Blackpool
arts.sum: Reading will need to overcome 'dogged and physically strong' Blackpool tonight if they are to extend their unbeaten run to 12 matches. The Royals are on their best run since 2012 and moved up to sixth in League One following Saturday's 3-1 victory over Peterborough United. Steve Bruce's Blackpool won 3-0 in Hunt's first home match in charge in December, while Bloomfield Road is a ground the Royals have not won a league match at since 2001. But in order to extend the unbeaten run and keep up their play-off charge, the Tangerines will need to be beaten.

arts.ttl: Why Reading could be kicked out of the EFL - takeover turmoil explained
arts.sum: Reading were once seen as the benchmark of how to run a football club - now they face an existential crisis after 153 years of history. Here's why…

arts.ttl: Former Reading star pays emotional tribute after sudden passing of brother
arts.sum: Former Reading midfielder Andy Rinomhota has paid an emotional tribute to his brother following his tragic passing in Thailand. The 27-year-old rose through the ranks with the Royals, making over 100 appearances and winning Player of the Season for 2019 before moving to Cardiff City in 2022. His brother, Joseph Itai Rinomhota, 30, reportedly died after receiving a kick to the ribs during a Muay Thai boxing match on the island of Koh Samui, Thailand.

arts.ttl: Noel Hunt has given us 'freedom to express ourselves' says Reading star
arts.sum: Reading star Charlie Savage has been full of praise for manager Noel Hunt, believing he has given the side 'freedom to express ourselves.' Savage, now a full Wales international, arrived in 2023 and is approaching 100 appearances for the club. A regular under Ruben Selles, albeit sometimes from the bench, Savage has stepped up a gear since Hunt took charge in November, scoring the third goal in Saturday's 3-1 win over Peterborough United. Now 11 matches unbeaten and in the play-offs with eight matches to go, despite another year of off-field turmoil, Savage could not speak higher of the new boss.
